greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Numbers formed by removing from n all duplicate digits except the leftmost copy of each.
comment: a(n)=n iff n is a term of A010784. a(n)<n iff n is a term of A109303.

A010784 is the sequence of distinct terms in this sequence, thus 9876543210 is the largest term here also, as no digit occurs more than once in any given term. Each term except 0 appears infinitely often in this sequence. - _Rick L. Shepherd_, Oct 03 2020
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..10000 (corrected by Andrew Howroyd at suggestion of Rodolfo Kurchan and Omar E. Pol, Oct 04 2020)
example: a(100)=10 as a (second) 0 digit is dropped. a(1211323171)=1237.
a(10...1) = 10 for any number of 0's and/or 1's in any order replacing the "..." in the term's index. - _Rick L. Shepherd_, Oct 03 2020
mathematica: Table[FromDigits@ DeleteDuplicates@ IntegerDigits@ n, {n, 74}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jun 01 2016 *)
program: (Perl) sub a {my($n)=@_; my @seen; $n =~ s{.}{!$seen[$&]++ && $&}eg; $n} # _Kevin Ryde_, Oct 04 2020
xref: Cf. A043529 (equivalent in binary, except at n=0), A337864.
results.author: _Rick L. Shepherd_, Jan 25 2008
